description: From French galop; named after the fastest running gait of a horse (see gallop), a shortened version of the original term galoppade.

entries.meaning: A lively French country dance of the nineteenth century, a forerunner of the polka, combining a glissade with a chass√© on alternate feet, usually in a fast 2/4 time.
The music for a dance of this kind.

verbs.description: galop (third-person singular simple present galops, present participle galoping or galopping, simple past and past participle galoped or galopped)
